reviewText: Burke & Wills combo is associated with famous explorers in and of Australia. Itself, this title just adds fun to a low-budget black-and-white Jarmusch-style Australian-produced movie of two young people walking along a life in modern Sydney. Seeking a job Will moved in to a Burke's place, being kicked out by psychotic girlfriend continuingly visiting him and seeking sexual favours even afterwards his initiating of a new affair with a different woman. Burke has clear communication problems and some money inherited made him no happy as he listened to sounds from Wills's bedroom. A film-with-twist received rather a less-than-more positive mark locally because, probably, a boring, meaningless ordinary Australian commoners' existence depicts average English-native blocks, usual heroes of worldwide-exported TV-sets of Aussie happy-ending serials running on fascinating landscapes of Sydney, not a customary sort of ethnic dole-bludgers born for and used mostly to improving their English skills endlessly while passively creating jobs for service-providers.

Make sure you read the reviews before you buy this product, because there are two Australian movies by this name.

The other one is a magnificent epic of exploration about the infamous Cooper's Creek expedition in which all but one of the expedition members died.  There are superb views of the Australian outback and a terrifying dust storm; the characterization is well done; and the acting is realistic.  I would give it a rating of 5.

This movie, of course, is not the one about Cooper's Creek.  If you're looking for that one, be warned.
